name: gig
content:
gig noun [C]
(PERFORMANCE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
informal a single performance by a musician or group of musicians, especially playing modern or pop music, or by a comedian (= a performer who makes people laugh, for example by telling jokes or funny stories): play a gig The band is going to Atlanta to play a gig at the Fox Theatre.do a gig The comedian did her first gig at the Comedy Store in London.
More examplesFewer examplesHe has been touring the globe and rocking audiences since his humble beginnings at bar gigs in Boston.We were asked to play at a benefit gig for charity.I much prefer a small intimate show to a faceless stadium gig.Kelvin loves to heckle when he goes to comedy gigs.

gig noun [C]
(JOB)
informal a job: get the gig She's well qualified, but I think it's unlikely she will get the gig.
More examplesFewer examplesTo get the gig at Saatchi & Saatchi, she wrote a 500-word essay about where she saw herself in 2024.He had a comfortable enough gig as coach at Yale.He finally landed a steady gig as a busboy in an Italian restaurant. Her latest gig is trying to win voters on the election campaign trail.
gig noun [C]
(VEHICLE)
a light two-wheeled carriage pulled by one horse, used especially in the past: He had the horse and gig brought to the door.
Science & Society Picture Library/SSPL/GettyImages
a light, fast boat for rowing (= moving using long sticks called oars) or sailing: We had no sail in the gig, but the larger boat was fully equipped.
More examplesFewer examplesWhy does he not keep a horse and gig of his own?My good friend the Doctor treated me to a very pleasant ride in his gig.The gaudy painted gigs and steam boats greatly enlivened a very busy and interesting spectacle on the river.The captain ordered a boat to be lowered, but the gig capsized.
